params.note: Initial SNR isolation via stereoscope is challenging; isolated tissue may contain no SNRs, a single SNR, or multiple rosettes. Such isolations often fail to generate multi-lumen organoids.
SNRs vary in size and shape within a single well; typically isolated SNRs are ≥200 μm in diameter with a clearly distinguishable single lumen. Mean size: 297 ± 3 μm (95% CI: 290.6–303.3 μm).
New methods using spatially confined micropatterned substrates can generate uniform SNRs with defined size and shape, potentially improving organoid consistency.
Organoid tissue lamination is non-uniform; regions with unclear or no organization are visually identifiable and excluded from imaging and electrophysiology analyses.
Common limitations of organoid protocols: absence of vasculature, microglia, and neuronal inputs from sensory organs or other brain regions.
Xenotransplantation of human organoids into rodent brain has been used to partially overcome these limitations.

Organoid generation protocol consists of five stages: (1) PS cell maintenance and propagation, (2) neural induction, (3) NR formation and isolation, (4) organoid formation from isolated SNRs, (5) organoid maturation.
CRISPR-Cas9-engineered human stem cells with large genetic deletions (e.g., ~69.5 kB SHANK3 excision) are generated for disease modeling.
scRNA-seq, immunohistochemistry, and slice patch-clamp electrophysiology are performed on SNR-derived organoids.
Use validated and characterized human stem cell lines; follow ISSCR standards. Include isogenic engineered controls for disease modeling.
Conditional CRE- or FLP-mediated induction/rescue of genetic abnormalities during differentiation is recommended for controlled studies.
